respondent.name: COMMISSIONER OF INTERNAL REVENUE; and ESTATE OF BURTON W. KANTER, DECEASED, ET AL., Petitioners v. No. 03-1034 COMMISSIONER OF INTERNAL REVENUE.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The Court will now hear argument in Ballard against the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. Mr. Shapiro.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Mr. Shapiro, can this case, in your view, be decided solely on the statutory question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: There also are due process allegations, and I'm not sure I even quite understand what the precise due process violation is that's alleged. But I would like you to address both and to tell us, first of all, how it would be resolved solely on a statutory basis 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 from your perspective.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, would that include - - if a Tax Court judge had a law clerk, would it include law clerk memos to the judge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, why -- why do you say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Would you elaborate for this 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 reason? Because the briefs and you again today keep talking about that first document. You use the word report.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, to me that's the whole conclusion of the case. I'm prepared to assume, at least for the moment, if you can convince me that that's the report they're talking about, you'd win. But that isn't what the Government says. The Government says that's a piece of paper, preliminary. We -- like my draft. I write drafts all the time. So -- so do trial judges. And he goes and brings the draft to the other two judges and says, let's sit down and talk about it. And they sit down and talk about it, and he changes his mind and writes a different document. And that different document, of course, is totally public. The whole opinion of the Tax Court. There is that document.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: How do we know that? Now - - now, what is the answer specifically in the statute? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Let's call it document 1 and document 2. And it really didn't help me that much in the briefs to see document 1 continuously labeled with the word report when I thought that's the key question. Is it? Is it that report they're referring to? So now, go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Which - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Which -- which brief - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: At least - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what page did you say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What -- what page?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Shapiro, why don't you simply read the text of 183(b) - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- which is in the Government's brief at 4a? It says, special trial judge's report. It is the only report to which the Tax Court rules refer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And -- and if in fact - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- you rely on the rule, do we even have to resolve the issue of meaning of report in the statute? Can't we simply, from your position, rely on the rule and say you've got to follow your own rules?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So you've really got three arguments. You've got the rule. You've got the statute, and you have due process.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Now, what -- what was the page? Please. You're going quite -- and I want to -- because Justice Ginsburg referred to a statement in the Government's brief that you said yes - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No, not the Government's brief. The Tax Court rules.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: 4a of the Government's brief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's the rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you make the argument that -- maybe you can't -- that the special trial judge can go to the Tax Court judge, with the permission of the chief judge, and say, now, here's what -- kind of what I'm thinking? It's not my report, but here's what I'm thinking. And then the -- the Tax Court judge says, well, why don't you have some more findings on X and Y and Z? He says, okay, and then he goes back. Can you make the argument that that first document is not the report?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I guess another way of 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 saying it is, do the rules permit any consultation before the report is submitted? I -- I guess that's my question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Would -- would that problem be overcome if the special trial judge simply -- if his - - the proceedings before him were simply videotaped and then the reviewing judge, Judge Dawson in this case, could look at the trial proceedings and would have as much of a notion of the credibility of the witnesses as the special tax judge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In which case, they -- they might well revise the language of their rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which currently requires that the finding of facts of the trial judge be presumed to be correct.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let -- let me ask this question, if I may. Suppose the -- a special trial judge 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 hears the witnesses, makes a report. It's assigned by the chief judge to a Tax Court judge, and the Tax Court judge looks it over it and says, you know, before I -- before I really spend a lot of time on this, you really didn't explore these three problems. Would you please do it over again? Is he permitted to do that or is that a violation of the rule that he shall presume the report to be correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm asking if it's a violation of -- of the rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Because the -- the rule says a special report shall be presumed to be correct.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And if there's this initial review, he says, you know, I think it's really pretty incomplete until you do X, Y, Z, please do it over again, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 is that a violation of the rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, what you're asking us to do would -- would just solve your problem in this case, and -- and in the future, I suppose they could revise rule 183 as simply not to require a report. There -- there's nothing in the statute that requires this report, is there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, they could -- they could use them, but just say, instead of filing a report, he'll consult with the -- with the deciding judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, they confer with each other. Maybe, maybe.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What happens in cases in agencies, you know, where -- where -- suppose the agency itself or a member thereof is going to make a decision, and there might be other members who would hear the witnesses. And I was thinking of that analogy. It's possible. It happens in the Federal Communications Commission where the staff, you know, consults back and forth in ratemaking cases.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's hard to find precisely the analogy, but it seems likely.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, which gives and takes away.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You have to have an opportunity to refute the information that's going to - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you analogize the STJ to the administrative ALJ. But you might also analogize him to a member of the agency itself, and if you make that analogy, it doesn't become so far-fetched, particularly when you look at Morgan as also not allowing you to probe at what's going on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Mr. Shapiro, is there any 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 evidence in this record that the special trial judge in fact changed his report beyond the hearsay affidavit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Shapiro, on credibility, which you have been emphasizing, are you overstating the case for it? Because credibility is more than just observing the witnesses' demeanor. I mean, Judge Dawson could have said, yes, they -- these witnesses might have looked honest to the special trial judge, but considering this documentary evidence in the record, it's clear to me that what the witness said on the stand was a lie.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Would -- would you comment on that? I -- I understood from the brief there was a suggestion that if you prevail, we're going to have a huge volume of -- of printed material that we're not troubled with now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, now, wait. Under the Due Process Clause, I assume you would be asking for more than just access to the report. You -- if -- if you're really relying on Morgan II, he who hears must decide, I think you would be saying that after reading the report, you should have the opportunity to argue to the -- to Dawson here, to -- to the Tax Court judge that the report should not be adopted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't that part of your due process case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You think it satisfies due process just to show you the report, and then - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, then -- then you're not relying on Morgan II.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There wasn't a need to disclose the point that Morgan II made. It was he who hears must 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 decide.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do -- do I understand that you would be satisfied if the Court simply looked to - - what is it -- 7482(a)(1), the appellate review section, which says that the Tax Court decisions shall be reviewed in the same manner and to the same extent as district court decisions? And that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And where is it? It's -- it is specified someplace, but when you review a district court decision in -- in a court of appeals, the - - certainly the magistrate's report would be included, but there's someplace where it lists the contents, some rule that lists - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Institutional memory. Isn't that -- that's a good institutional memory - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That -- that was decided under the APA, wasn't it? I mean, that was an APA case, which this isn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Would the -- the Tax Court rule -- now, this 183(c) -- says -- it describes the special trial judge's report, which is submitted to the chief judge, and then the chief judge assigns a Tax Court judge, and then it says that -- that the Tax Court judge may modify it, modify the special trial judge's report, or may reject it in whole or in part. Does the Tax Court ever modify a special trial judge's report? Does it ever reject it in whole or in part?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that's one thing that they can do. They can adopt it, but my question is, do they always adopt and never use -- never use the term modify or reject?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They -- they never say so in their opinion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They always say that they adopt the trial judge's report. Don't they? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What -- what is -- can I ask you a really esoteric administrative law question, which I have never been able to figure out? It's probably relevant, but I -- this is an agency. That's what -- my great tax professor, Ernie Brown, used to say there is no Tax Court. He says, the Board of Tax Appeals shall be known as the Tax Court. What he meant by that is it's not -- it isn't the Tax Court, just known as. So -- so this is an agency, an administrative agency. So I look to the APA for guidance, and the APA, when you look at the section, says this initial decision can be made by a 556-qualified person. Now, a 556 - qualified person can include the agency itself or a member of the agency or an ALJ. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Then when you to look at what happens in 557, after that presiding employee makes an initial decision, it says you have to give a chance to the party to respond to the initial decision, which you like, in the case where the presiding employee -- presiding person is a subordinate employee. And so, that's what I was just checking here. And so -- so what's supposed to happen where the presiding person under 556 for that initial or tentative decision is not a subordinate employee, but rather, quote, one or more members of the body which comprise the agency? I've never run into that before. Maybe you haven't. Maybe they didn't mean anything by it, but maybe they did.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He was a subordinate employee?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Rather than a member -- is - - is -- if he's a subordinate employee, that's easy. Then the case is easy I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: These -- these - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you're -- you're not asserting that the APA governs this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No. I'm just looking - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't there an express exception for -- for - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The -- the special trial judge has no tenure, does she?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, you may, of course. Mr. Hungar.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Hungar, before you proceed to your legal argument, I was very curious why the Government is defending this practice because the Government, after all, is on the other side of every case. And aren't there situations where it might be that the special trial judge would call a credibility question in the Government's favor and then the Government loses the case before the Tax Court judge and might like to know, before it goes to the court of appeals, how solid the credibility findings were? I mean, I -- I -- the Government being a party to all these proceedings, why is it satisfied with not knowing what the report of the special tax judge -- special trial judge was? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No, it is not the report. It is called an opinion. It isn't even called the report, and if you will read 183(b), that describes the report. Does anything else describe the report? And what is this report? There is a report. It is submitted to the chief judge. What would you call that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Now, what is the 183(b) report?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So that report, the special trial judge's report, is a document prepared by the special trial judge which he gives to the chief judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But that's not the way the rule reads. The rule reads, as I understand it, under (c) that the court itself may accept, reject, or modify. It doesn't say anything about the special trial judge reconsidering and rewriting his report.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, it does because it -- it goes on to say that due regard shall be given to the circumstance that the special trial judge had the opportunity to evaluate and the findings of fact recommended by the special trial judge shall be presumed to be correct. But if those findings of fact are simply the same findings of fact that he agrees with the rest of the -- the panel on, it just makes no sense at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What report goes to the chief judge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's a report. Is that not a report?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why doesn't that -- why isn't that required to be -- to be made public?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's a report. The statute says that the reports have to be made public.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That is a report.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it goes to the - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but the rule -- the rule says that the first report, the document 1, has to be given deference. Whether it's presumed to be correct.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Sure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, it's -- it's very hard to understand how appellate review can function if that first report of the special trial judge is never disclosed. I just don't see how the appellate review can function properly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And how do we know that it was -- that it was presumed to be correct under the rule? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes. How does the appellate court know whether deference, as required by the rules, was given unless the appellate court can see it? It's such a strange procedure. Why, in answer to Justice Ginsburg, does the government take the view it does? Wouldn't you like to see it if it went against you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, the rule --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- the rule -- the rule 183 does provide for a certain degree of deference to be given to those findings of the special trial judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Hungar, do you - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do you see somewhat of a problem, that we are not dealing here with the relationship between peers? Judge Dawson is appointed, what, for a 15-year term. The special trial judge is appointed by the Tax Court and his job is at the Tax Court's grace. And if you have compared in your brief that relationship to, say, a discussion among colleagues, I think it's worlds different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: He has had a special -- a - - a long term and he is well-known and respected as a Tax Court judge who was appointed, as all other members of the court were appointed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It seems to me - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It seems to me that it's very much like, if you have to compare it with something, the relationship between a magistrate and a Federal district court judge. The magistrate also hears testimony, makes a report, findings, and a recommendation. What's the difference between those two?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So where does it say that? Where does it say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: They're not requiring the - - this case doesn't involve the question of whether they can make objections to the finding in -- in the special report. It's just whether it's disclosed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, I understand. But your argument about how it would make the proceeding more cumbersome, it seems to me, is -- is misplaced.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But they're not asking for that. Am -- am I wrong on - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And it's a particularly strong argument in a case -- in several of the issues. I remember Judge Fromm's opinion turned on the credibility of oral testimony, and in one case, Judge Fromm found the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- the judge here made an erroneous ruling on credibility on one issue, if I remember correctly. And it seems to me that's a case in which it would be particularly relevant to know the reasons pro and con on why credibility determinations were made by the person who heard the witnesses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Has been convinced that he was wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And the question is, well, what was his -- what was the basis for his original position when you're evaluating whether you've got a valid argument to make on appeal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, no, no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Only if he is required by a rule to make certain findings and to deliver a completed report to someone else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It doesn't forbid it. You're right. It doesn't forbid it in so many words. But I just wonder, does it comport with your normal notions of a fair way to conduct a fair hearing, letting the parties know what the basis for decision was and who thought what about the witnesses and so forth?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No. But I don't see what is consistent with your notion of a deliberative process as producing the report and the presumption of correctness in the rule. The rule presumes that some original document, which you are treating as provisional, enjoys a presumption of correctness, and I don't see the consistency between provisionality and deliberate character on the one hand and presumption on the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And aren't those findings of fact the findings of fact that are delivered to the chief judge in the report that is made to the chief judge before it is even assigned to a Tax Court judge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But he hasn't abandoned them at the point that he delivers them to the chief judge, and if that's what this is referring to, then the presumption of the -- of -- of correctness necessarily has to apply to whatever the document is that's delivered to the chief judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You're -- you're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why isn't that explained in the rules, if that's the process?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- have a condition subsequent. It seems to me that you're saying, Mr. Hungar, that the last sentence of 183 is unenforceable. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: The presumption.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So you're saying the rule itself in that respect is invalid?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, how else could you possibly construe it? There's no presumption operating at all on your reading.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but you're saying there is -- there is no presumption of correctness that can operate with respect to the report that goes first to the chief judge because, I understood you to say, to do that would violate the Internal Revenue Code provision that the fact- finder and the only fact-finder is the Tax Court judge. And therefore, I think the implication of what you're saying is that the rule on its face is invalid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm not even getting to whatever the standard of review may be. I presume the word presumption means something other than it's there unless you want to change it later after the person who employs you objects to it. It's got to mean something more than that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But there's no party who is seeking to change at this point because the parties don't know what's in it. They're not going forward. This is, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 as you point out, an internal process that is going on here. So that definition can't apply.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In -- in that discussion, does the Tax Court judge have to give great weight to the findings of fact of the -- of the special judge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Any weight?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So I -- I think your -- I think your answer then is not that this is invalid. It is simply unenforceable. It is precatory language, looks okay, but there's no way to police it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Judicially it cannot be enforced.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do they -- do they ever? I mean, this -- this says, this decision -- it's labeled - - the -- the court agrees with and adopts the opinion of the special trial judge. Are there Tax Court cases where the Tax Court says, instead of that, the court modifies the decision of the special trial judge or the court rejects, in whole or in part, the report of the special trial judge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do Tax Court opinions come 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 out that way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Because if one were just to rule this -- read this rule straight: first, the report that goes to the chief judge, and then it says that the Tax Court judge may modify it, reject it in whole - - adopt, modify, or reject in whole or in part. You would expect, if we were having truth in labeling, that whenever, with consultation, without, there's a difference between the two documents, the Tax Court judge, in combination with the special trial judge or without, would say, action on the report -- action on the report, which is the special trial judge's report, is it is modified or it is rejected or it is rejected in part. I mean - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The rule -- the rule doesn't say anything about this consultation that you've described. And if that's the Tax Court's procedure, why isn't it laid out in the rules so everyone can see it instead of being deceived by reading here is the special trial judge's report, and now what the Tax Court will do is either adopt, modify, or reject in whole or in part?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Misleading. Because when I just read this rule cold, that's what I assumed, that we have the initial report and then it goes to the Tax Court judge, and that judge does something with it, and that something may be adopt, it may be modify, it may be reject in whole or in part.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I don't think there's any - - any question they can change the report, but the one - - the one -- I'd like to ask you a question as a matter of information. The first sentence of 183(c) refers to the possibility that the judge to whom the case is assigned may direct the filing of additional briefs to receive further evidence and oral argument. Does it ever happen that before the judge to whom it's assigned decides 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 whether or not to go along with the recommended findings, that he will direct oral argument? Does that ever happen?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because if he did, it would seem almost necessary for him to disclose to the parties what the report they're arguing about would say.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But it certainly seems to contemplate deliberation by the judge to whom the case is assigned about whether or not to accept the report and deliberation which might be informed from input -- input from the parties. That's a fair reading of the rule, I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Maybe it's not practiced.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And if he did then ask for 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 further briefings, do you think that there would then have been a requirement to disclose the report?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It seems to me that the author of this subsection (c) must have contemplated the possibility of disclosure of the report.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: When they followed a different procedure, and the question is to how much -- how much did they intend the -- to change that prior procedure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does the statute you just quoted prohibit the disclosure of other reports if we call this first draft something other than a report?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In other words, would -- would the rule go further than the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Hungar, you started to say that -- that even the opinion of a -- of a Tax Court judge 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 is not a report of the Tax Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How does that work?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I was -- I was going to ask you what -- what 7461 referred to when it says the Tax Court and its divisions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It also is referred to there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I see.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So it's a single judge is a division of the Tax Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the publicity of proceedings does say -- it does say that all reports of the Tax Court --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And all evidence received by the Tax Court and its divisions, meaning its single judges. Well, what happens with -- with a single judge's opinion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's like an en banc. I -- I have written decisions for a panel in my years on the court of appeals, and there's been an en banc and my opinion gets vacated. It's no longer counts for anything. And isn't that exactly what the Tax Court is? They have the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Oh, no. No, no, no. How often, when there is a decision reviewed by the court, so that the initial judge's decision is changed, does that judge dissent, so all the world knows what that judge's initial position was?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then he -- then he can publish his -- he can publish his dissent, just as a Tax Court judge can?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But then we still won't know what his report is. Yes, he can say, I won't sign this. Tax Court says, fine. This rule says I can reject your findings in whole or in part. I don't need your name on this decision of the Tax Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'm asking you just as the - - the judge who disagrees with the -- the full court can publish his dissent, can the special trial judge who disagrees with the Tax Court judge publish his dissent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Has there ever been? Has there ever been?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And how -- how often does the -- is there a dissent when there's -- when there's a full court review decision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Except that the -- the relationship between the -- the one judge and the full Tax Court is a relationship basically of people who are in the same boat with respect to what they know about or can know about law and what they can know about the evidence and the facts of the case; whereas the relationship between 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the special trial judge and the judge to whom it is assigned is -- is quite different because only one of them has heard evidence and only one of them is the source of conclusion about fact.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It certainly is not identical in -- in the sense that the -- the Tax Court judge then goes and listens to evidence. He doesn't. That's the whole point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Neither does the full Tax Court, but if the full Tax Court is disagreeing with one judge, the one judge and the full Tax Court are in the same boat. They have access to the same material. Their limits are exactly the same in each case. That is not true in the relationship between the single Tax Court judge and the special Tax Court judge. The special Tax Court judge is the only one who has heard evidence and can find facts based upon the evidence that he heard.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I -- I am quite aware of that. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 That's not -- that's not the point. I'm -- I'm saying that you cannot draw an analogy between one judge and full Tax Court and use that as an analogy to legitimize the relationship between one judge and a trial master. They are in different positions. They are not in parallel positions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It's the knowledge issue. The special Tax Court judge heard somebody.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Nobody on the Tax Court did.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: In other words, they're - - they're sitting hearing witnesses? They are -- they are redoing the trial? Surely not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But we are talking about situations in which the trial judge is the special judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Hungar, I think we understand your answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Shapiro, you have about 4 minutes left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why does 7461 require its - - its disclosure? Because it does say that the -- it's only the decision of the Tax Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That reports of the Tax Court that have to be disclosed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that -- that would mean that -- that you would have to make public the -- the reports of a regular Tax Court judge in cases that then go on to the full court. And that's not done, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, but it doesn't matter. It would still be a report of the Tax Court if you don't take that language literally. If you say any report coming out of the institution is a report of the Tax Court, you would have to make public the reports of the individual Tax Court judges, which is not done. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why is that? What -- what statute is that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's not a -- that's not a de novo -- they can rehear matters de novo on the en banc Tax Court, can they not? That's a de novo hearing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't know if I'm getting - - so that's his basic point. The rule doesn't require the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 disclosure because they've interpreted it differently within their -- within their discretion. Statute doesn't require it and the Constitution doesn't require it. We have to go to the Constitution, I don't see exactly the implications. So I'm nervous. And now, the reports -- he says, go read 7460(b). That's what they're talking about. And then - - and again, I don't know what I'm getting into once I read it more broadly than that. And what about all evidence received by the Tax Court, including a transcript. Of course, this isn't evidence but neither is a transcript. And -- and so maybe that word evidence can be read more broadly, given the fact that it's to include a transcript of the stenographic report.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You think I'm right just suddenly for the for the first time? You have thought of this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There's -- there's a very 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 careful use of language. It says all reports of the Tax Court and all evidence received by the Tax Court and its divisions. So it's only the evidence that -- that's received by the individual judges has to be made public, not the reports.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But we -- we don't have to get into any of that if we accept your argument about 7482(a)(1), that is, the record will be in the same manner and to the same extent as decisions of the district court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Shapiro. The case is submitted.
